description: Windows 7 is still a viable option out in the IT world and is one of the most commonly used desktop operating systems today. This series covers routine administrative tasks that any Desktop Support Technician or Help Desk Technician would be expected to handle on a regular basis including installation and deployment, managing and maintaining, and operational issues one may encounter supporting Windows 7 as an enterprise level technician.
name: Supporting Windows 7
subtitle: Configuring and maintaining Windows 7

episodes.description: Windows 7 is one of the most commonly used desktop operating systems today. This series covers routine administrative tasks that any Desktop Support Technician or Help Desk Technician would be expected to handle on a regular basis.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:07.584
[SOUND]
In this segment,

2
00:00:07.584 --> 00:00:10.610
we're gonna introduce you to a new
show that we have lined up for you.

3
00:00:10.610 --> 00:00:12.720
It is supporting Windows 7.

4
00:00:12.720 --> 00:00:16.460
Now this doesn't line up
with any exam per se, but

5
00:00:16.460 --> 00:00:20.350
the Windows 7 is still a viable option
out there for you in the IT world.

6
00:00:20.350 --> 00:00:22.780
So, you do need to be
able to support that guy.

7
00:00:22.780 --> 00:00:25.330
So, Ronnie, you have done a great job of

8
00:00:25.330 --> 00:00:29.210
coming up with a list of things that
we're gonna go over in this show.

9
00:00:29.210 --> 00:00:30.100
So, I want you to help us out and

10
00:00:30.100 --> 00:00:31.760
show these good people
what we're talking about.

11
00:00:31.760 --> 00:00:35.394
>> All right, we've got to remember that
even though we are now at least at Windows

12
00:00:35.394 --> 00:00:38.539
10, the very fact is most enterprises,
and even most home users,

13
00:00:38.539 --> 00:00:41.360
are probably still running Windows 7,
and that accounts for

14
00:00:41.360 --> 00:00:44.110
about 65% of the world's
PCs that are out there.

15
00:00:44.110 --> 00:00:46.960
And that means we as technicians, whether
or no you're actually working in the large

16
00:00:46.960 --> 00:00:50.310
enterprise, or whether we're working
in a small home environment,

17
00:00:50.310 --> 00:00:53.388
that we need to be able to have
those technical skills ready to go.

18
00:00:53.388 --> 00:00:56.460
So, if you actually did
come in doing Windows 8 and

19
00:00:56.460 --> 00:00:57.790
now we're actually supporting Windows 10.

20
00:00:57.790 --> 00:00:59.890
Those are great things
to actually focus in on.

21
00:00:59.890 --> 00:01:02.690
But remember that you have
a lot of the world marketplace

22
00:01:02.690 --> 00:01:04.165
that's still on Windows 7.

23
00:01:04.165 --> 00:01:06.660
And what we wanted to do is we
wanted to produce a show that would

24
00:01:06.660 --> 00:01:10.570
help us to actually be able to say, look,
here's what a technician needs to know.

25
00:01:10.570 --> 00:01:13.610
So, this is more about
the troubleshooting aspects of somebody,

26
00:01:13.610 --> 00:01:16.070
actually in the field,
needing to support Windows 7.

27
00:01:16.070 --> 00:01:20.150
And what we did is we broke up our content
into three separate sections here.

28
00:01:20.150 --> 00:01:23.920
We talked about installation and
deployment.

29
00:01:23.920 --> 00:01:26.070
We'll also go over managing and
maintaining.

30
00:01:26.070 --> 00:01:30.430
And then lastly, we talk about the idea of
operational issues that we may encounter

31
00:01:30.430 --> 00:01:33.700
as we are supporting Windows 7 as
an enterprise level technician.

32
00:01:33.700 --> 00:01:36.390
Let's go ahead and take a look at some
of these topics that we'll be covering

33
00:01:36.390 --> 00:01:38.420
in this show coming up here.

34
00:01:38.420 --> 00:01:41.390
So underneath installation and
deployment, we will be talking about

35
00:01:41.390 --> 00:01:44.650
basic installation issues that
we do end up encountering.

36
00:01:44.650 --> 00:01:47.010
And this is when we actually
just put in the disc and

37
00:01:47.010 --> 00:01:49.620
something ends up happening and
it's not what we expect.

38
00:01:49.620 --> 00:01:51.180
We talk about how to
troubleshoot that as well.

39
00:01:51.180 --> 00:01:55.980
We'll also take a look briefly

40
00:01:55.980 --> 00:01:59.170
This ends up happening a lot
of times when we are actually

41
00:01:59.170 --> 00:02:02.970
trying to create an image for our

42
00:02:02.970 --> 00:02:05.830
What are some of the key points
that we need to take a look at

43
00:02:05.830 --> 00:02:08.560
to make sure that we can actually
the image the way that we want to?

44
00:02:08.560 --> 00:02:11.230
We even go into a little about
creating an answer file as well.

45
00:02:11.230 --> 00:02:14.210
And then lastly,
working with their deployment server.

46
00:02:14.210 --> 00:02:16.900
What are some of the encounters
we can have there as well?

47
00:02:16.900 --> 00:02:19.910
And those are some of the different
techniques that we talk about underneath

48
00:02:19.910 --> 00:02:22.070
installation and deployment.

49
00:02:22.070 --> 00:02:26.270
When we move into the managing and
maintaining area, we now actually talk

50
00:02:26.270 --> 00:02:30.920
about some of the basic concepts that we
as technicians need to be familiar with.

51
00:02:30.920 --> 00:02:32.870
If you're working in an active
directory environment,

52
00:02:32.870 --> 00:02:37.170
the idea of working with policies
are actually clear for what we need to do.

53
00:02:37.170 --> 00:02:39.600
A lot of times that's gonna
be handled a level above

54
00:02:39.600 --> 00:02:42.090
what we're actually doing
as a support technician.

55
00:02:42.090 --> 00:02:45.340
But we do need to understand how that
actually effects the operating system.

56
00:02:45.340 --> 00:02:48.320
And so, we also deal with it
in terms of a local policy

57
00:02:48.320 --> 00:02:51.370
as well as the active
directory group policy too.

58
00:02:51.370 --> 00:02:53.910
We then take a look at
monitoring Windows 7.

59
00:02:53.910 --> 00:02:56.190
And normally, when we start
to take a look at monitoring,

60
00:02:56.190 --> 00:02:59.000
we're really trying to take a look at
the performance issues that end up

61
00:02:59.000 --> 00:03:02.760
working inside of Windows 7
against us a lot of times.

62
00:03:02.760 --> 00:03:05.970
And we as technicians need to know that
the tools that are actually built in there

63
00:03:05.970 --> 00:03:08.760
will help us to effectively be
able to troubleshoot some of

64
00:03:08.760 --> 00:03:12.110
those performance issues, isolate what
the issue may be, and even try and

65
00:03:12.110 --> 00:03:14.240
solve and correct those as well.

66
00:03:14.240 --> 00:03:17.370
Of course, that means that we also
need to deal with security issues.

67
00:03:17.370 --> 00:03:19.820
And these types of security
issues always pop up,

68
00:03:19.820 --> 00:03:22.070
especially with the idea of the browser.

69
00:03:22.070 --> 00:03:25.270
Windows 7, by default,
actually just has Windows, or

70
00:03:25.270 --> 00:03:28.200
Internet Explorer 8 actually
as their default browser.

71
00:03:28.200 --> 00:03:31.100
But you can update that and
that solves a lot of the issues.

72
00:03:31.100 --> 00:03:34.200
But what are some of the other things
that we need to be familiar with?

73
00:03:34.200 --> 00:03:36.720
And especially when we actually
go to the different websites and

74
00:03:36.720 --> 00:03:39.800
they don't work the same way that we a,
are expecting them to.

75
00:03:39.800 --> 00:03:42.680
We need to think about that as
well as malicious software.

76
00:03:42.680 --> 00:03:46.440
And of course, updating some of
the policies involved in that as well.

77
00:03:46.440 --> 00:03:47.060
And then, or course,

78
00:03:47.060 --> 00:03:51.630
in security, we also talk about file
encryption as well as drive encryption.

79
00:03:51.630 --> 00:03:53.592
And we talk about that
a little bit more in-depth,

80
00:03:53.592 --> 00:03:56.140
so that you understand that these
are issues that also come up.

81
00:03:56.140 --> 00:03:58.527
And we're really taking a look at
all of this from the troubleshooting

82
00:03:58.527 --> 00:03:59.650
standpoint, right?

83
00:03:59.650 --> 00:04:01.560
Not that you know how to
implement everything,

84
00:04:01.560 --> 00:04:03.460
because more than likely you already do.

85
00:04:03.460 --> 00:04:06.200
But what are some of the things
that you may end up encountering

86
00:04:06.200 --> 00:04:07.120
that you're not sure of.

87
00:04:07.120 --> 00:04:11.655
And so, we actually do spend the time
in focusing in on that as well.

88
00:04:11.655 --> 00:04:14.970
We also of course, take a look at just
basic networking connectivity issues that

89
00:04:14.970 --> 00:04:19.150
we have to deal with, and name resolution,
as well as the command line utilities that

90
00:04:19.150 --> 00:04:22.540
we end up using a lot of times
that we're troubleshooting.

91
00:04:22.540 --> 00:04:27.145
And then of course, accessing things like
files and other resources in our network.

92
00:04:27.145 --> 00:04:31.120
Lastly, we also wanted
to address of course,

93
00:04:31.120 --> 00:04:35.470
operational issues that tend to come and
plague us as people supporting Windows 7.

94
00:04:35.470 --> 00:04:37.480
The idea that applications and

95
00:04:37.480 --> 00:04:40.850
installing applications can be
complex in most environments.

96
00:04:40.850 --> 00:04:45.470
But in today's world, it actually is
a lot easier than it was at one time.

97
00:04:45.470 --> 00:04:48.390
When we were moving from
Windows XP to Windows 7,

98
00:04:48.390 --> 00:04:50.350
we may have had some technical issues.

99
00:04:50.350 --> 00:04:52.340
And a lot of those have now been resolved.

100
00:04:52.340 --> 00:04:53.930
But at the same time,

101
00:04:53.930 --> 00:04:57.970
you may still be supporting a line of
business application in the background,

102
00:04:57.970 --> 00:05:00.965
and you're not exactly sure what you
can do to deal with that as well.

103
00:05:00.965 --> 00:05:02.640
We'll also take a look at that.

104
00:05:02.640 --> 00:05:05.950
Of course, the UAC,
as well as hardware-related issues.

105
00:05:05.950 --> 00:05:09.550
And then lastly,
the idea of using accessibility, and

106
00:05:09.550 --> 00:05:11.770
of course availability options too.

107
00:05:11.770 --> 00:05:15.320
That really does help someone that
may have some type of disability, or

108
00:05:15.320 --> 00:05:18.570
some type of other issue that they're
facing, and they actually just need to

109
00:05:18.570 --> 00:05:22.000
be able to work with Windows 7
a little bit more effectively.

110
00:05:22.000 --> 00:05:23.340
As support technicians,

111
00:05:23.340 --> 00:05:27.790
the very fact is we can't just be
centric towards one operating system.

112
00:05:27.790 --> 00:05:30.410
Being able to support Windows
7 is actually a great skill to

113
00:05:30.410 --> 00:05:31.040
have on your hand.

114
00:05:31.040 --> 00:05:35.170
And so, if you are actually supporting
this type of operating system

115
00:05:35.170 --> 00:05:37.780
in your Enterprise environment, or
you go, you want to know something,

116
00:05:37.780 --> 00:05:41.110
I may actually moving on to another
job and they're running Windows 7, and

117
00:05:41.110 --> 00:05:43.329
even though I'm actually, you know,
more familiar with Windows 8,

118
00:05:43.329 --> 00:05:45.620
I need to actually get a little
more familiar with it.

119
00:05:45.620 --> 00:05:47.030
This is actually the show for you.

120
00:05:47.030 --> 00:05:49.510
And so,
if you are really interested in this,

121
00:05:49.510 --> 00:05:52.480
this is the show you really want to
watch if you're especially interested in

122
00:05:52.480 --> 00:05:54.690
being able to troubleshoot some of
the issues that we talked about here.

123
00:05:54.690 --> 00:05:55.200
>> That's right.

124
00:05:55.200 --> 00:05:58.050
Lots of great information there for
a Windows 7 environment.

125
00:05:58.050 --> 00:06:01.784
So if you're still having to find yourself
supporting Windows 7, or if you just wanna

126
00:06:01.784 --> 00:06:04.905
round out your skill set and make sure
that you are relevant no matter what

127
00:06:04.905 --> 00:06:08.563
shop you're working in, we look forward
to seeing you in these upcoming episodes.

128
00:06:08.563 --> 00:06:15.299
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel describe some of the issues that may arise when doing a basic installation of Windows 7. Here they detail problems you may encounter regarding the boot media, the drive and/or device drivers, and the partitioning of the drive and what you can do to alleviate the trouble.
episodes.title: Basic Installation Issues

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie show you how to create a Windows 7 image for deployment to multiple computers and how to avoid some of the common issues you may encounter when performing that task. They show you how to boot into the Audit mode, how to create an answer file using the Windows Auto Installation Kit, and how to use Sysprep to take advantage of that answer file.
episodes.title: Image Creation Issues

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie show you how to use Windows Deployment Services to create and deploy a Windows image over a network connection. They also identify some of the common issues you might encounter when employing this type of installation. Topics covered are taking a PC image, choosing and image, and PXE boot.
episodes.title: Deployment Issues

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike take an in depth look at access control. They look at NTFS permissions, both standard and special. Then they demonstrate how NTFS permissions are inherited, and how to change the way permissions are inherited.
episodes.title: Access Control

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike continue their look at access control. They talk about how NTFS permissions are cumulative, as well as permission precedence. They finish things up with a look at share permissions, and how they combine with NTFS permissions.
episodes.title: Access Control Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike look at installing and troubleshooting printers. They talk about installing local printers and network printers. They look at adding printer drivers.
episodes.title: Printer Access

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike look at security settings in Internet Explorer. They talk about protected mode, and how to prevent disabling it. They also show how to manage trusted sites and add-ons. They also show how to launch IE without add-ons and InPrivate Browsing.
episodes.title: Internet Explorer Security

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike look at ways to detect and prevent malicious software. They use tools like the services console, msconfig, and task manager to determine what is running on a machine. They also look at the settings available in UAC, and how to configure them using Group Policy.
episodes.title: Malicious Software

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike talk about security best practices. They discuss the importance of updates, and what to do if an update fails. They also look at encryption options, like EFS and Bitlocker.
episodes.title: Security Best Practices

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike look at troubleshooting network connectivity issues. They talk about determining the scope of the issue, and how that affects troubleshooting. They examine tools like ipconfig, ping, and netstat, and how to use them when troubleshooting.
episodes.title: Network Connectivity Issues

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike look at common DNS issues. They discuss DNS related ip configuration, APIPA addresses, and releasing and renewing DHCP leases. They also look at flushing the DNS cache, and using nslookup.
episodes.title: Name Resolution Issues

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike discuss VPN protocols and issues related to them. They talk about IKEv2, SSTP, L2TP, and PPTP, and what some of the common problems associated with each protocol.
episodes.title: VPN Client Issues

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike talk about software installation failures. They look at common problems, like rights needed to install software, and application requirements like external access. They also look at Applocker and Software Restriction Policies.
episodes.title: Software Installation Failures

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike look at troubleshooting software failures. They discuss the Event Log system, and creating Event Log subscriptions. They look at options like repairing the installation, and reimaging the system. They also talk about running the application in a previous OS version.
episodes.title: Software Failures

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Ronnie take a look at user logon issues.  The majority of these issues may end user error that technicians need to be able to identify, according to the guys.  They also talk reducing these issues. Using the auditing features found in the event viewer helps to identify issue.s  Also they mention issues that may prevent users from running applications on the computer as well as how the Windows Firewall helps with basic security
episodes.title: User Accounts & Basic Security

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike take a look at some of the hardware issues that end users often mention.  They take a look at managing drivers. They also mention that memory issues can be problematic and talk about the memory diagnostic tool that can help identify a problem module and they take a look at disk management tools and the use of diskpart to help when adding additional drives for use.
episodes.title: Hardware Related Issues

episodes.description: In this episode Mike and Ronnie take a look at configuring accessibility and availability features in Windows 7. They show how to support such features such as Narrator, Magnifier and Sticky Keys. By exploring these features, a technician can troubleshoot accessibility options whether they should be enabled or not.
episodes.title: Accessibility & Availability
